comments.raw_text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:8.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/8.0.1
Build ID: 20111120135848

Steps to reproduce:

Opened a page with characters such as ▓ ▒ ░ in the title.  Then opened a second tab, then back to the first tab, then opened a different page.


Actual results:

After opening the second tab, the characters in the first tab changed (grew taller).  After opening a different page in the first tab, portions of these characters remained.


Expected results:

The characters should not of changed and should not of partially remained.
comments.creator: jjackson@post.com
comments.author: jjackson@post.com

Steps to reproduce:

Opened a page with characters such as ▓ ▒ ░ in the title.  Then opened a second tab, then back to the first tab, then opened a different page.


Actual results:

After opening the second tab, the characters in the first tab changed (grew taller).  After opening a different page in the first tab, portions of these characters remained.


Expected results:

The characters should not of changed and should not of partially remained.

comments.raw_text: Problem did not occur in safe-mode, but did occur using the default theme and disabling all extensions and plugins.  I'm not sure how to troubleshoot further.

comments.raw_text:
(In reply to Jason Jackson from comment #0)
> Steps to reproduce:
> 
> Opened a page with characters such as ▓ ▒ ░ in the title.  Then opened a
> second tab, then back to the first tab, then opened a different page.

Does the last step mean that you opened the different page in the same tab as the first tab?

comments.raw_text:
(In reply to Andre Klapper from comment #2)
> Does the last step mean that you opened the different page in the same tab
> as the first tab?

Yep.

I think your summary removed what is probably the real problem: the characters changed and became rendered (in what I assume is) outside of the area designated for text.
comments.creator: jjackson@post.com

comments.text: Can you try disabling HW acceleration in Options->Advanced->General? Restart Firefox and try the site.
comments.creator: acelists@atlas.sk
comments.raw_text: Can you try disabling HW acceleration in Options->Advanced->General? Restart Firefox and try the site.

(In reply to :aceman from comment #4)
> Can you try disabling HW acceleration in Options->Advanced->General? Restart
> Firefox and try the site.

That eliminated the problem!  I'm intrigued, what's going on to cause that?
comments.creator: jjackson@post.com

comments.author: jjackson@post.com
acelists@atlas.sk
comments.text:
HW acceleration is using different rendering libraries (Direct2D vs. cairo).

Justin, is the component still right after this find?
comments.creator: acelists@atlas.sk
